author: sky.cactus
content: If you all think an appropriate change control process is the EIP system, then I think it is reasonable.  If you all would prefer to have a separate change control process then I think that is okay as well.

author: sky.cactus
content: My gut tells me that the indtdal spec won't go through the EIP process, but future changes to the spec post-release would.  The EIP process is good for small change sets, not as good for giant change introductions like ETH2.

author: sky.cactus
content: Another option is to treat ETH2 as a primitive.  EIPs often refer to keccak256 but the specification for that is not defined in EIPs anywhere.  So one could imagine an EIP that says "as of fork block number, the block header will be `ssz(a,b,c,d,e,f)` where `d` is calculated using using ETH2PoS" or something.  So it is a technical specification, it just refers to ETH 2 spec as a primitive.
